node.title: May 2021 News
node.bodyText: May 2021 News

node.title: Question on coupling between phase field and tensor mechanics
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE team,
I have few general questions regarding the coupling between phase field and tensor mechanics:
By default, a single phase field simulation uses Eulerian/spatial meshes that don't deform, while a single tensor mechanics simulation uses Lagrangian/material meshes that will deform. When they are coupled together, which mesh type is used?
If the material meshes are used, how do we think about the mass conservation in a coupled RVE? For instance, if we have solid and gas phases in a RVE, the solid will flow in/out of the domain due to the mass diffusion, thus the total mass can not be conserved inside the RVE, which gives problem justifying the mass periodicity at the boundary.
If spatial meshes are used, how do the meshes deform? Or how do phase field variables influence the traction at the boundary?
Hope you could give me some insights/hints to the questions. Thanks in advance.
Best regards,
Hao
Can you formulate your phase field equations on a deformed configuration? You can potentially solve phase field equations on a deformed mesh by setting use_displaced_mesh = true.

I think it depends on the phase field model. If his phase field describes an Eulerian interface, then he has to use some Eulerian-Lagrangian methods to couple with tensor_mechanics. If his phase field is Lagrangian, there is no issue.
I doubt this is related to use_displaced_mesh.

You shouldn't need use_displaced_mesh = true unless you have large deformation. For small deformations, we have coupled phase-field with mechanics without any issues.
Which phase-field model are you using?  In general, phase-field does not change the volume and you shouldn't need to track the interface. Maybe explain what you are trying to do in a bit more detail.

Okay, I want to simulate the densification in a solid state free sintering with a RVE, then we could apply mechanical loads with different micro-structure at different densities to check homogenized mechanical properties. If I consider free sintering without external load in a periodic RVE, there are in general two ways to achieve densification: 1. fix domain and let mass flow into this domain at the boundary; 2. keep total solid mass constant and shrink the total domain volume. As material will flow/move inside the domain due to diffusion and advection, the domain boundary should also move accordingly. This is where I got into Eulerian-Lagrangian settings of the RVE. But you pointed out in general the phase-field does not change the volume, would it still be possible to achieve densification using the phase-field method?

The densification from a phase-field sintering simulation is calculated in terms of the reduction in free surfaces and/or internal porosity. You can find some of our sintering work in the following papers,
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2352431616300438
https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10853-017-1846-3
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0927025619305877

Thanks for sharing the interesting papers, they are really helpful. In the first two papers, the mechanical loads are applied to the boundary with prescribed displacements instead of the traction boundary with fixed loads, the solid and void phases are lumped together like a composite material and the composite elasticity tensor is used in the mechanical equilibrium calculation. If one uses the stress at the boundary instead, would it lead to some convergence problem like mesh distortion as void phase has very low elasticity so they could not carry any loads? In your second paper, the last figure with 2 particles deforming in 3D looks very nice, but they deform so much at the end and would small deformation assumption still be valid there?
The last paper gives a good overview on the density evaluation methods during sintering, the MC algorithm to evaluate the relative density seems to be a good approach. But all the methods need a post-process step and seem difficult to correlate to homogenization. If one wants to shrink the domain with a global strain that corresponds to local particle movements, how would you suggest to achieve this in MOOSE?

Yes, instead of the applied displacement, you can use the pressure boundary condition. To avoid numerical issues, you will have to assign a small non-zero stiffness for the void.  Yes, in the 3D example, the deformation was kept within the elastic limit.
You can change the volume of an RVE using the GlobalStrain approach. See here, https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168874X20301165

Yes, I get you applied small non-zero stiffness for the void phase, the only thing I am still puzzling is that when you apply a pressure load on the top of a 2D domain with particles in the center and not touching the boundary, the void phase will take the load first and deform, then transfer to solid phase. If the void stiffness is very small, the deformation on void elements will be much larger than on solid phase, or in other words, void phase could not take any loads, only solid phase can, how is the problem overcome in this setting? Maybe I misunderstood how the two phase composite works in mechanical module...
The second paper looks very promising, is there a way to correlate particle rigid body motion to the GlobalStrain? Because in all the paper it clearly stated that rigid body motion is the key point to the volume shrinkage during sintering... If this feature is not there, maybe I could contribute in developing it, then I probably will need more help/guidance from the expert like you.

The stiffness of the void was selected in a way to avoid such issues. Also, for small displacement problems, the calculation is done on the undisplaced mesh. No, GlobalStrain has not been connected to rigid-body motion.

Thanks for explanations, maybe connecting rigid-body motion with GlobalStrain is a way out to my problem, it will be a GlobalStrain only coming from stress free rigid-body motion, or purely due to diffusion induced rigid-body motion, how would you suggest to do this in MOOSE?

node.title: hydraulic-head gradient (initial condition)
node.bodyText:
Hi guys,
I am trying to set a hydraulic-head gradient on 3D geometry, is there any simple method to work around this.
I tried to set the side boundary with different gradients but that doesn't give me the results I want (I want it to follow the red line as attached).
Thank you guys.
@WilkAndy I think you are the expert on this topic, you might be able to quickly help, thanks!
Kind regards,
Traiwit
[ICs]
  [./porepressure]
    type = FunctionIC
    variable = porepressure
    function = ini_pp
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
     [./pp_z2]
       type = DirichletBC
       variable = porepressure
       boundary = 'back'
       value = -9810000
     [../]
     [./pp_z1]
       type = DirichletBC
       variable = porepressure
       boundary = 'front'
       value = 0
     [../]
     [./water_grad_x1]
       type = FunctionDirichletBC
       variable = porepressure
       boundary = 'bottom'
       function = watergradx1
     [../]
     [./water_grad_x2]
       type = FunctionDirichletBC
       variable = porepressure
       boundary = 'top'
       function = watergradx2
     [../]
[]

[Functions]
  [./ini_pp]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    axis = z
      x = '0 900 1000'
      y = '-9810000 0 0'
  [../]
  [./watergradx1]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    axis = z
    x = '0 900 1000'
    y = '-9810000 0 0'
  [../]
  [./watergradx2]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    axis = z
    x = '0 700 1000'
    y = '-9810000 0 0'
  [../]
[]
okay guys, think about it again, this is physically impossible, since the fluid level probs should be controlled by Pc. Moreover, the fluid contact in the same hydraulic system should be flat.

In steady-state, given the same BCs on all the vertical sides of the model (eg, hydrostatic) this head configuration is impossible, as you note.  However , these types of hydraulic gradients are always observed in nature.  This is usually because of some sort of recharge that is happening at y=-big (in your model) - often in some nearby mountain range - and discharge that is happening at y=big (in your model) - often in a valley or floodplain or ocean, etc - along with an aquitard "cap" in the model domain that prevents vertical movement of water to the topography.
To get this initial condition in a model can be difficult or hard, depending on how you approach the problem.  You can take the hard route by extending your model domain so it includes the recharge and discharge points, and running a sequence of models with different recharge/discharge and hydraulic properties until your model matches observations.  This is possibly the "best" type of modelling approach since it most strongly suggests you've got a model that reflects reality.  However, doing the calibration to observation is rather time consuming, and often when you extend the model you're encountered with a bunch of unknowns, which makes your model "weaker" since you have to somehow prescribe hydraulic properties, lithologies, recharge zones, etc, that you don't know anything much about.
Instead, you often simply fix the BCs such that the steady-state matches your observations, without worrying too much about why or how those boundary conditions arise.  Of course, this would be inappropriate if the observations have been influenced by recent water abstractions (in this case, the BCs might be simple hydrostatic, but the ICs would be what you describe).  In MOOSE, you could useFunctions to define these BCs and ICs.  I often use a ParsedFuntion, and always try to use only 1 or a small number of such Functions (e.g. use the same function in all BCs and ICs).  Throughout the aquifers you can assume hydrostatic, unless it disagrees with observations.  These hydrostatic lines "jump" as you go through the aquitards.   I hope you understand what i mean: as you move vertically the porepressure (or head) looks like a lightning bolt: ⚡ .
a

Noted, thank you @WilkAndy,
May I have a quick question about the excavation with hydro.
How do I let the pore-pressure of the excavated block = 0, it seems that I cannot control it via [Materials] block like Young modulus.
From your coal-mining problem, I see you control it with the Sink term (but that is at the boundary)
I am not sure if it's possible to do the same in the middle of the geometry.
Kind regards,
Traiwit
  [./roof_porepressure]
    type = PorousFlowPiecewiseLinearSink
    variable = porepressure
    pt_vals = '-1E3 1E3'
    multipliers = '-1 1'
    fluid_phase = 0
    flux_function = roof_conductance
    boundary = roof
  [../]

  [./roof_conductance]
    type = ParsedFunction
    vars = 'end_t ymin ymax   maxval minval'
    vals = '0.5   0    1000.0 1E7      0'
    value = 'if(y<ymin+(ymax-ymin)*min(t/end_t,1),maxval,minval)'
  [../]
Why do you care about the porepressure in an excavated block, since it has been removed from your model?

true that's a very valid point, so basically I should just set porepressure BC around the excavated block to be 0 to model the movement of the fluid after excavation.
Thanks again @WilkAndy

Yep, a DirichletBC or FunctionDirichletBC will do nicely, i think.   (The advantage of the PorousFlowPiecewiseLinearSink is that you have a bit more control on how much water is coming into the excavation, but DirichletBC will be fine for you.)

Perfect got it, thanks again @WilkAndy

  [add_side_sets_block6]
    type = SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator
    block = 6
    input = add_side_sets
    normals = '0  0  1
               0  1  0
               1  0  0
               0  0 -1
               0 -1  0
              -1  0  0'
    fixed_normal = true
    new_boundary = 'front6 top6 right6 back6 bottom6 left6'
    variance = 0.5
  []

  [./water_grad_block6]
            type = FunctionDirichletBC
            variable = porepressure
            boundary = 'front6 top6 right6 back6 bottom6 left6'
            function = pp_block6
  [../]

[./pp_block6]
    type = ParsedFunction
  value = 'if(t>2,0,-9.81*1000*(1000-z))'
  [../]

node.title: Error in loading Microstructure from Dream.3D
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE team,
I tried to load the polycrystal microstructure from Dream.3D to perform grain growth simulation. But I am getting an error. Do you know how to resolve this error.
Dream.3D Export:

Here is my input file moose input script: grain_growth.i.txt
And the Dream.3D microstructure file: grain_size10.txt
This is my error
*** Warning, This code is deprecated and will be removed in future versions:
EBSDMesh is deprecated, please use the EBSDMeshGenerator instead. For example:

[Mesh]
  type = EBDSMesh
  filename = my_ebsd_data.dat
[]

becomes

[Mesh]
  [ebsd_mesh]
    type = EBDSMeshGenerator
    filename = my_ebsd_data.dat
  []
[]
Stack frames: 14
0: libMesh::print_trace(std::ostream&)
1: void moose::internal::mooseDeprecatedStream<ConsoleStream const, char const (&) [238]>(ConsoleStream const&, bool, char const (&) [238])
2: EBSDMesh::EBSDMesh(InputParameters const&)
3: std::shared_ptr<MooseObject> moose::internal::buildObj<EBSDMesh>(InputParameters const&)
4: Factory::create(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, InputParameters&, unsigned int, bool)
5: SetupMeshAction::act()
6: Action::timedAct()
7: ActionWarehouse::executeActionsWithAction(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)
8: ActionWarehouse::executeAllActions()
9: MooseApp::runInputFile()
10: MooseApp::run()
11: ../.././bull-opt() [0x40272c]
12: __libc_start_main
13: ../.././bull-opt() [0x40296e]

Uniformly refining mesh                                                                    [  1.00 s]


*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "ebsd_reader", of type "EBSDReader".

Data points must be on the interior of the mesh elements. In EBSDReader ebsd_reader

Stack frames: 18
0: libMesh::print_trace(std::ostream&)
1: moose::internal::mooseErrorRaw(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >)
2: callMooseErrorRaw(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >&, MooseApp*)
3: void MooseObject::mooseError<char const (&) [73], std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&>(char const (&) [73], std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&) const
4: EBSDReader::indexFromPoint(libMesh::Point const&) const
5: EBSDReader::readFile()
6: EBSDReader::EBSDReader(InputParameters const&)
7: std::shared_ptr<MooseObject> moose::internal::buildObj<EBSDReader>(InputParameters const&)
8: Factory::create(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, InputParameters&, unsigned int, bool)
9: FEProblemBase::addUserObject(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, InputParameters&)
10: Action::timedAct()
11: ActionWarehouse::executeActionsWithAction(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)
12: ActionWarehouse::executeAllActions()
13: MooseApp::runInputFile()
14: MooseApp::run()
15: ../.././bull-opt() [0x40272c]
16: __libc_start_main
17: ../.././bull-opt() [0x40296e]
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
[unset]: write_line error; fd=-1 buf=:cmd=abort exitcode=1
:
system msg for write_line failure : Bad file descriptor


Regards,
Kamal
I also tried to update the mesh type to "EBSDMeshGenerator" but it gave another error saying that the "init_mesh" is not a registered task.

I think that particular error message may be out of date (also an issue, but a separate one from this): Try changing your block to this (e.g. drop that middle layer of nesting)
[Mesh]
    type = EBDSMeshGenerator
    filename = my_ebsd_data.dat
[]

If this fixes the intermediate error, please let us know so we can update the error message to be more useful.

Hi !
Sorry to respond late. I was on holidays.
No. it does not fix the error.

I believe I ran into this error a few years ago. I have some notes on it at the office but since we are working from home I don't have access to it. If I remember right, the problem comes from an error in how Dream3D writes data out. As you see in grain_size10.txt, it puts the data points on x=-32, y=-32 etc. This sits right on top of the boundaries of the elements, which is what the error message is saying. I believe I was able to work around this by changing X_MIN, Y_MIN, Z_MIN, X_MAX, Y_MAX, Z_MAX manually in the text file so they did not align exactly with the locations of the data points.

So, If I make  X_MIN=-32.0001, will it work ? Also, Each data-point from Dream.3D will taken as a nodal data point. Or Each data-point in Dream.3D will taken as elemental point in MOOSE.

Thanks,
Kamal
…
________________________________
From: Larry Aagesen ***@***.***>
Sent: Monday, March 29, 2021 4:20 PM
To: idaholab/moose ***@***.***>
Cc: Kadirvel, Kamal ***@***.***>; Author ***@***.***>
Subject: Re: [idaholab/moose] Error in loading Microstructure from Dream.3D (#17440)


I believe I ran into this error a few years ago. I have some notes on it at the office but since we are working from home I don't have access to it. If I remember right, the problem comes from an error in how Dream3D writes data out. As you see in grain_size10.txt, it puts the data points on x=-32, y=-32 etc. This sits right on top of the boundaries of the elements, which is what the error message is saying. I believe I was able to work around this by changing X_MIN, Y_MIN, Z_MIN, X_MAX, Y_MAX, Z_MAX manually in the text file so they did not align exactly with the locations of the data points.

—
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://github.com/idaholab/moose/discussions/17440*discussioncomment-545492__;Iw!!KGKeukY!nbFVmDHLvuy-J5BfPP6MHX1pdtZkkM9DBTc1X_w_ZHIVPW7RNqFDw4JBf3LLO9tEmSWCg-_A2KI$>, or unsubscribe<https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AIUJ4LMJL6PJYNWQ46V2JCDTGDOKTANCNFSM4Z5R2KZQ__;!!KGKeukY!nbFVmDHLvuy-J5BfPP6MHX1pdtZkkM9DBTc1X_w_ZHIVPW7RNqFDw4JBf3LLO9tEmSWClIk2Ic8$>.
I think I actually shifted everything by -0.5. But changing to X_MIN=-32.0001 X_MAX=31.9999 would probably also work. Give it a try

I'm not very familiar with Dream3D, but I've worked quite a bit with the EBSD data that it produces. I believe the reader that we have generates the mesh to line up at nodes (not elements). You can see that here:

  
    
      moose/modules/phase_field/src/meshgenerators/EBSDMeshGenerator.C
    
    
         Line 144
      in
      c9c0f8f
    
  
  
    

        
          
           _xmax = nr[0] * _geometry.d[0] + _geometry.min[0]; 
        
    
  


The EBSD reader code is fairly straight forward in that we grab all of the geometry information from the EBSD data file itself to build the mesh. We have a few examples of working EBSD meshes checked in that you can review for how it works:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/phase_field/test/tests/grain_tracker_test/test.txt
Thank you very much for your inputs. after shifting everything to -0.5, it works fine.
can you please provide the dream3d pipline of your grain_size_10.txt file ? I tried to make a similar test just like yours ,but the feature id is mach more than 200 and my sever not calculate .

node.title: Error Executing an Input File (Tutorial 01)
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone, I'm on Step 2 of the tutorial, and after following the instructions to execute the  'pressure_diffusion.i' file, I keep getting:
*** ERROR ***
Unable to open file ... Check to make sure that it exists and that you have read permission.
I've tried the other execution methods listed, I've googled around, and I've changed permissions for both the file and the folder it belongs to, but nothing seems to work. I also tried putting it in the simple_diffusion folder from the previous example, but I just received a different error.
Any advice would be greatly appreciated.

Hello
Can you please paste the command you are running and the content of the directory with the permissions (ls -l)
Best,
Guillaume

command: ../babbler-opt -i pressure_diffusion.i
contents and permissions: pressure_diffusion.i  pressure_diffusion.i.txt
Sorry if the permissions aren't there- I'm using Windows, and the most analogous commands I could find were 'dir' and 'ls', which gave me the same list

You mean Windows Subsystem for Linux right?
If you have ls, you could try ls -l

Yes, thank you; it gave me the following:
total 8
---------- 1 rl3fz rl3fz 1497 Jun  3 15:24 pressure_diffusion.i
---------- 1 rl3fz rl3fz 1550 Jun  4 18:17 pressure_diffusion.i.txt

-------- means you have no permissions over these files. It should look something like -rw-rw-r-- giving you and your user group the right to write and read those files.
So could you please use chmod +rw pressure_diffusion* then report back
-the ls -l output
-whether you can run the input file now

ls -l output:
-rw-r--r-- 1 rl3fz rl3fz 1497 Jun  3 15:24 pressure_diffusion.i
-rw-r--r-- 1 rl3fz rl3fz 1550 Jun  4 18:17 pressure_diffusion.i.txt
And it worked! Solve Converged! Thank you very much!

Note that a common reason for permissions to be broken in WSL is that you are editing these files, then saving them, from a Windows text editor. I am not sure what the fix is. It's actually working fine on my machine with Atom.

node.title: Libmesh error
node.bodyText:
I'm getting this error while trying to build libmesh:
error: invalid conversion from ‘MPI_Comm {aka ompi_communicator_t*}’ to ‘TIMPI::communicator {aka int}’ [-fpermissive]
this->_comm->get() = PETSC_COMM_SELF;
Any suggestions what could be causing this? I've not had this problem previously.
Ignore that, looks like a module wasn't loaded. Seems to be fixed now.

Hi Wenkun
You need to make sure that the MPI library you are loading has been compiled with the compiler you are trying to use.
What do mpicc --version and 'gcc --version' return?
Nothing wrong with one-api a priori, but keep in mind you are loading both the gcc and the intel compilers here, so you need to be careful about consistently using the same one, and be careful about which mpi library is being used if one is included in your one-api module.
I do not recommend loading all the intel suite just to get a python module. You can get python through anaconda.
If you have a support team for your cluster, I recommend they help you install moose. They will be aware of what has been loaded in each module that they created.
Guillaume

I have tried to follow up with them like what I did here but they are not responding to my query after :( so again I really appreciate your patience with me.


StdEnv   2) cmake/3.14.2-gvwazz3   3) valgrind/3.13.0   4) intel-oneapi/2021.2.0.2883   5) gcc/9.2.0-pkmzczt
mpicc --version and gcc --version both return gcc (GCC) 9.2.0


StdEnv   2) gcc/10.2.0-z53hda3   3) mvapich2/2.3.4-blues-lf335hv   4) cmake/3.18.4-fygx2f7
mpicc --version and gcc --version both return gcc (Spack GCC) 10.2.0


StdEnv   2) gcc/7.4.0   3) mvapich2/2.3-blues-hgzwj2b   4) cmake/3.14.2-gvwazz3   5) valgrind/3.13.0   6) anaconda3/5.2.0
mpicc --version and gcc --version both return gcc (GCC) 7.4.0
I don't know why I got the the error message about not having support for C++11 with my compiler...

So I just learned that intel compilers are not supported by the way.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/manual_installation_gcc.html

2 or 3 should all work afaik.
What do the CC and CXX environment variables point to?

Thanks to @GiudGiud , the problem is solved. For those who may have similar problems and don't want to go through all the replies above. A short answer for this question is to make sure that CC and CXX point to mpicc and mpicxx after you load your modules.

node.title: Two Questions on P-F
node.bodyText:
Hello,
Please see below two questions on P-F.
Thank you.
John Sevic
Q1.
In the file direct_order4_test.i located at (modules/phase_field/test/tests/PolynomialFreeEnergy/direct_order4_test.i) there are two references, Brown1980 and Balluffi1978, is there a master reference section that precisely defines these references.
Q2.
Please refer to the attached screen captures returned when I run direct_order4_test.i Any suggestions? I should probably update my MOOSE, if that helps.

Hi John,
The references for phase-field documentation are listed at projects/moose/modules/phase_field/doc/content/bib/phase_field.bib. Unfortunately I don't see either of the listed references there and it looks like this input file pre-dated the documentation system anyways. The person who added this input file no longer works at INL so I'm afraid it might not be that easy to track down this reference.
The error you are getting indicates you need to update your PetSC library and likely MOOSE as well.

Building and linking hit...

failed to import pyhit - try running "make hit" in the $MOOSE_DIR/test directory.

Following the steps on: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html

Did you run
conda create --name moose moose-libmesh moose-tools
conda activate moose

as listed on the page you linked?
The fact that your install looks for libmesh within the moose directory and not a conda directory leads me to believe that you did not.
I did

And what is the result of
echo $LIBMESH_DIR

?

I removed MOOSE and tried to reinstall it several times and I got repetitively the following error:
CondaHTTPError: HTTP 000 CONNECTION FAILED for url https://mooseframework.org/conda/moose/osx-64/current_repodata.json
Elapsed: -
An HTTP error occurred when trying to retrieve this URL.
HTTP errors are often intermittent, and a simple retry will get you on your way.
'https://mooseframework.org/conda/moose/osx-64'

Please see this announcement and follow the instructions: https://groups.google.com/g/moose-announce/c/6-eXRa3mJmA/m/lGbpo31RAQAJ
After following those commands, you should be able to remove any old environments with the name moose:
conda env remove --name moose

and then re-add it:
conda create --name moose moose-libmesh moose-tools

Go to compile, and before doing so activate the environment:
conda activate moose
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make -j 4

I did and received the same error. I ran
almeag-mac@FN601235 test % echo $LIBMESH_DIR
almeag-mac@FN601235 test %
It return anything.

make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....
/bin/sh: /Users/almeag-mac/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/libtool: No such file or directory
make: *** [/Users/almeag-mac/projects/moose/framework/src/utils/RankFourTensor..opt.lo] Error 127
/bin/sh: /Users/almeag-mac/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/almeag-mac/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory

/bin/sh: /Users/almeag-mac/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/almeag-mac/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/almeag-mac/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory

/bin/sh: /Users/almeag-mac/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/libtool: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/almeag-mac/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/almeag-mac/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/almeag-mac/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
Using HIT from /Users/almeag-mac/projects/moose/framework/contrib/hit
/bin/sh: /Users/almeag-mac/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
Building and linking hit...
bash: -std=c++11: command not found
make: *** [hit] Error 127
failed to import pyhit - try running "make hit" in the $MOOSE_DIR/test directory.

You're still not properly activating the conda environment. If the conda environment is active, $LIBMESH_DIR will be set to a directory.
I suggest that you remove miniconda with rm -rf ~/miniconda3 and follow the directions again. You're missing a step somewhere.

I use this command:
curl -L -O https://repo.anaconda.com/miniconda/Miniconda3-latest-MacOSX-x86_64.sh
bash Miniconda3-latest-MacOSX-x86_64.sh -b -p ~/miniconda3

The remainder of the instructions are very important.
If LIBMESH_DIR is not set, you are most likely not following them in their entirety.

Assuming the conda reinstall went fine (to check could you please run conda list moose, thanks!)
I think you're just missing the conda activate moose step

almeag-mac@FN601235 test % conda activate moose
CommandNotFoundError: Your shell has not been properly configured to use 'conda activate'.
To initialize your shell, run
$ conda init <SHELL_NAME>

Currently supported shells are:

bash
fish
tcsh
xonsh
zsh
powershell

See 'conda init --help' for more information and options.
IMPORTANT: You may need to close and restart your shell after running 'conda init'.
Please follow the instructions - this is explained clearly in the end of the section "Install MOOSE Conda Packages" and there are even frequently asked questions about this issue on the page.

@AhmedAlmetwally
did you do what the error message says?
conda init zsh
then close and reopen the shell.
Then conda activate moose should work.
Please let us know how this goes
@GiudGiud @loganharbour, Thank you so much! It compiled now properly conda initiation.

node.title: Mesh File  Not Able to Use Interface Functions
node.bodyText: I have modified an fsi model that incorporates the use of a mes file instead of a mesh block definition. When I try to execute the model I get an error that states SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator, and SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator wil not work with a mesh file. Is there an equivalent to these interface functions that will work with a mesh file?

Hello
Use a FileMeshGenerator to load your mesh file, then it should work.
Guillaume
Thank you very much!
